unnormalised: India's population has crossed a major milestone! The latest provisional data from the 2023 census suggests the country now has over 1.4286 billion people. That's a lot of folks, right? The census, conducted by the Office of the Registrar General & Census Commissioner, shows a growth of approx 17.7% over the 2011 census figures.
normalised: india's population has crossed a major milestone! the latest provisional data from the two thousand and twenty three census suggests the country now has over one point four two eight six billion people. that's a lot of folks, right? the census, conducted by the office of the registrar general and census commissioner, shows a growth of approximately seventeen point seven percent over the two thousand and eleven census figures.

unnormalised: Breaking it down, the data shows Uttar Pradesh is still the most populous state, with a whopping 241 million residents! Maharashtra comes in second at around 125 million. Smaller states like Sikkim, on the other hand, have populations below 700,000. The population density has also increased to 475 people per sq km across India.
normalised: breaking it down, the data shows uttar pradesh is still the most populous state, with a whopping two hundred and forty one million residents! maharashtra comes in second at around one hundred and twenty five million. smaller states like sikkim, on the other hand, have populations below seven hundred thousand. the population density has also increased to four hundred and seventy five people per square kilometer across india.

unnormalised: Interesting tidbit: the sex ratio has improved slightly, with 935 females per 1000 males now, compared to 933 in 2011. Also, the literacy rate is now reported to be at 77.7%, showing an improvement from the earlier 74.04% figure.
normalised: interesting tidbit: the sex ratio has improved slightly, with nine hundred and thirty five females per one thousand males now, compared to nine hundred and thirty three in two thousand and eleven. also, the literacy rate is now reported to be at seventy seven point seven percent, showing an improvement from the earlier seventy four point zero four percent figure.

unnormalised: Analysts say this data will be key for policy decisions, resource allocation and overall planning. The full report, with detailed breakdowns by age, caste, and religion, is expected to be released by the end of 2024. Seems like we're all set for a very crowded future, folks!
normalised: analysts say this data will be key for policy decisions, resource allocation and overall planning. the full report, with detailed breakdowns by age, caste, and religion, is expected to be released by the end of two thousand and twenty four. seems like we're all set for a very crowded future, folks!
